Art.description: The guy with the graphical manikins that everyone knows
Art.title: Keith Haring
Art.content:
• Born: 4. May, 1958
  • Died: 16. February, 1990
  • Nationality: American
  • Movement: Pop art, street art
--- Does everyone know about Keith Haring? Most likely, yes. At the very least, people are familiar with his distinctive art style. Is that a negative thing? No, not at all. He aimed for his art to be widely viewed, not limited to traditional art galleries, and to be accessible to everyone. He gained recognition by creating chalk doodles in subway stations, performing live painting in public areas, and painting murals in schools located in underprivileged neighborhoods. He also collaborated with AIDS activists. It’s somewhat ironic that his rebellion against the elitist art world institutions has resulted in a large consumer market, where a lot of money is involved. In addition to everything else, I really appreciate the aesthetic of his iconography style.

Art.title: Jean Jullien
Art.content:
• Born: 14. März 1983
  • Nationality: French
  • Movement: graphic artist
--- I keep stumbling across illustrations and graphics by Jean Jullien, whether in magazines, social media or bookshops, and I know immediately that they are by him. I love how unique yet simple his style is and how he uses them in the most diverse ways - for example for prints, clothing or flower pots. It is definitely worth taking a look at his work

Art.title: Shirley Jaffe
Art.content:
• Born: 2. October, 1923
  • Died: 29. September, 2016
  • Nationality: American
  • Movement: Abstract expressionism, geometric art
--- Since I found out about Shirley Jaffe’s work, I’ve really enjoyed her sensitive use of geometric shapes. There’s something special about how she mixes those geometric shapes with so much dynamic in her pieces. I first saw her art at an exhibition in Basel, and it really stuck with me. It’s cool how her art shows the creative spirit of the post-war era but still feels fresh and modern today! She is one of the artists who inspires me to get back into creative coding. Her graphical style would be perfect for recreating algorithmically. ## Exhibition Snapshots from my visit to the Shirley Jaffe exhibition in Basel on June 7, 2023 ![](https://res.cloudinary.com/daxsvl9cg/image/upload/f_auto/v1729331356/obsidian/ocwnfkc8shkzkjupxhc8.jpg) ![](https://res.cloudinary.com/daxsvl9cg/image/upload/f_auto/v1729331385/obsidian/nskanrdbmhf4o6fb8lcr.jpg) ![](https://res.cloudinary.com/daxsvl9cg/image/upload/f_auto/v1729331384/obsidian/kzkshzcnhjpigzsfakkb.jpg)

Art.description: Expressionist painter and co-founder of Der Blaue Reiter
Art.title: Gabriele Münter
Art.content:
• Born: 19. February, 1877
  • Died: 19. May, 1962
  • Nationality: German
  • Movement: Expressionism, Der Blaue Reiter
--- Gabriele Münter is one of those artists who got overshadowed for too long by the men around her, especially Wassily Kandinsky, with whom she had a relationship for over a decade. But her work stands completely on its own and deserves way more recognition. What I find fascinating about her paintings is how she simplifies forms and uses bold, flat colors. There's a directness to her work that feels almost modern, even though she was painting over a hundred years ago. Her landscapes and portraits have this beautiful balance between abstraction and representation. She was a key figure in founding Der Blaue Reiter alongside Kandinsky and Franz Marc, which was one of the most influential expressionist movements. After World War I and her separation from Kandinsky, she continued working but largely stepped away from the public art world. One remarkable thing she did was hide and preserve a huge collection of avant-garde art during the Nazi era when such works were labeled "degenerate art". She later donated over 80 of her own works and many pieces from her collection to the Lenbachhaus in Munich, which now has one of the best collections of Blaue Reiter art in the world.

Books.description: memoir about running and life in general
Books.title: What I Talk About When I Talk About Running – Haruki Murakami
Books.content:
Haruki Murakami and running? I’m all in!

This book is far more than just a memoir by Haruki Murakami about his routine of running. It is about the joy of doing something stoically day after day to influence life, creativity and the view of the world. It is about the themes of self-discovery, perseverance, and the human condition.

Murakami reflects on his own struggles with identity, creativity, and purpose, and how these challenges have shaped him into the person he is today. It's always interesting to get a glimpse inside Murakami's head.

Books.title: Circe – Madeline Miller
Books.content: Before reading this book, I knew very little about Greek mythology – maybe that Zeus, Poseidon and Hades were associated with Greece, but nothing more. However, Madeline Miller has made the topic engaging, accessible, and exciting for me. Her writing inspired me to explore more about the topic while I was reading and after finishing the book. I even subscribed to a podcast on the subject, can you imagine? There is something fascinating about the fact, how the ancient Greeks used gods, titans, and olympians and other concepts to explain the world, life, and the uncertainties that come with it and giving meaning to their experiences.

Books.description: a Young Adult take on The Iliad
Books.title: The song of Achilles – Madeline Miller
Books.content: I really enjoyed reading «Circe» by Madeline Miller, so I decided to read her take on the Trojan War and explore more Greek mythology. Unfortunately, I didn’t enjoy this book as much. The relationship between the main character, Patroclus, and Achilles didn’t resonate with me; it felt too melodramatic and one-dimensional. Additionally, the writing style and the abrupt structure of the chapters didn’t draw me in. I still like the genre of historical fiction and the greek mythology, which made the book interesting enough for me to finish, but it didn’t capture my curiosity about this new world like «Circe» did.

Design.description: Taste is how you organize your inner world. What you let in. What you keep out.
Design.title: Taste
Design.content:
> In an age where AI can generate anything, the question is no longer "can it be made?" but "is it worth making?" The frontier isn’t volume—it’s _discernment_. And in that shift, taste has become a survival skill. [^1]

> Taste is how you protect your mental environment. When you sharpen your discernment, you stop being swayed by trends. You stop needing consensus. You stop reacting to every new thing like it’s urgent. [^1]

> Our ‘personalised’ feeds, paradoxically, made our tastes boringly predictable and our attention spans alarmingly short. The content algorithms have flattened our sensory experience, training us to crave whatever triggers the quickest dopamine hit rather than what actually nourishes us. [^2]

> (...) in a world where the cheapest dopamine wins by default, taste is how you opt out. Not to impress anyone. But to protect your soul. [^1]

[^1]: https://wildbarestepf.substack.com/p/taste-is-the-new-intelligence
[^2]: https://www.densediscovery.com/issues/345/

Design.title: Cultural Sensitivity in Design
Design.content:
As someone who creates digital products both professionally and privately, I, like everyone else in the industry, should consider culture in designs.

I came across this topic via the great YouTube videos by Phoebe Yu[^1], who, for example, explains why websites in Japan look very chaotic, crowded and supposedly "badly designed" from a European/Western perspective. But they are not - they just take different cultural values, preferences and tastes into account. It's not just about the visual appearance, but also how processes in digital products are built.

It's a very exciting topic that I would like to learn more about (and should).

[^1]: https://www.youtube.com/@phoebeyutbt

Design.description: Set of guidelines===== to make design decisions
Design.title: Design Principles
Design.content:
![design principles](https://res.cloudinary.com/daxsvl9cg/image/upload/f_auto/v1728048253/obsidian/nesjsumjmbxdxy08ioeu.webp)


## 1. balance
Balance refers to the distribution of visual weight in a design. There are two main types of balance: symmetrical (even distribution) and asymmetrical (unbalanced distribution). The aim is to create a harmonious overall picture.

## 2. contrast
Contrast involves emphasising differences between elements in the design. This can be achieved by using color, size, shape or texture to create visual interest and highlight important elements.

## 3. emphasis
This principle focuses on emphasising a main element or message in the design. It draws the viewer's attention to the most important thing and helps to establish the hierarchy.

## 4. movement
Movement refers to the way in which the viewer's eye is guided through the design. This can be achieved through lines, direction, pattern or animation to create a visual flow.

## 5. repetition
Repetition involves using recurring elements such as colors, shapes or fonts to create consistency and coherence in the design. This helps to create a uniform appearance.

## 6. hierarchy
Hierarchy defines how elements in the design are organized to show their importance and relationship to each other. This makes it possible to emphasize important information and create a clear structure.

## 7. white space
White space refers to the unused space in the design that remains between elements, text and graphics. It creates space and facilitates visual processing. Less can often be more.

## 8. unity
Unity means that all elements in the design fit together and form a coherent whole. This is achieved by applying the other principles to ensure that the design is cohesive and appealing.

Photography.description: purposely moving the camera while the shutter is open
Photography.title: Intentional Camera Movement (ICM)
Photography.content:
A photography technique where you move the camera while taking a photo, intentionally introducing blur and distortion into the image. This creates a sense of dynamism and movement through blur and distortion.

Some common techniques:

* **Panning**: Moving the camera horizontally to follow a moving subject. By following a subject in motion at the same speed while the shutter is open, you get an exciting effect. The subject remains in focus and the background blurs into motion distortion.
* **Tilting**: Rotating the camera to create a sense of depth or perspective.
* **Swirling**: Moving the camera in a circular motion to create a dynamic, abstract effect.
* **Shaking**: Gently shaking the camera to introduce subtle blur and distortion.

Projects.description: Notes on the project you are currently viewing
Projects.title: Digital Garden
Projects.content:
## What is a digital garden?

A digital garden is a method for organizing and sharing knowledge, thoughts, and ideas in a flexible and interconnected way. The notes don’t have to be polished or finished; they can be shared as incomplete ideas that will develop over time and ideally create new connections, which may eventually lead to the development of a blog post or similar content to share fresh insights.

I have decided to publish my digital garden, which I already maintain for myself locally in Obsidian, on my personal website, as one or the other note might be exciting for you and initiate new thoughts and ideas.


## How did I build my digital garden?

I use the software Obsidian to create, edit, and organize my notes, and it’s convenient because I can do this on both my smartphone and laptop. The app automatically adds important information like creation dates, editing dates, and footnotes, which makes it user-friendly. I wanted the process of creating and maintaining notes to be straightforward, without any technical challenges, so I would actually use it.

My Obsidian Vault syncs automatically with GitHub whenever I make changes. Each day, the latest version of my GitHub project is automatically fetched from my personal website and shown in this digital garden, so I don’t have to manually deploy my local changes.

- [ ] add backlink logic to other notes
- [ ] support for nested categories/folders

- [ ] add "random note" feature for sidebar navigation
- [ ] dynamic open graph images for notes and topics

Psychology.description: You're a unicorn, according to some generic horoscope
Psychology.title: The Barnum effect
Psychology.content:
### What is the Barnum Effect ?

Imagine someone tells you that "you're a very special person" or "you have a unique personality." You might think, "Wow, that's true! I am special!" But the thing is, those statements are so general and vague that they could apply to almost anyone.

This is called the Barnum effect. It's when people take general statements as being specifically about them, even if they're not really true or specific.


### How AI advice can trigger the Barnum Effect 

As more and more AI apps enter the realm of personalised guidance, we're becoming more susceptible to the Barnum effect.

We accept generalised advice that applies to almost everyone else as personal observations. For example, you wrote an entry in one of those AI-powered journal apps, that you've been feeling demotivated at work lately.

Trying to come up with personalised advice the journal app writes: _"Your feelings of lost motivation may stem from a deep-seated need to make a significant impact in your field."_

This is the Barnum effect in full swing. While the statement is valid and relatable, the loss of motivation you feel right now might be different. You might just be burned out after an exhausting project, or the work itself doesn't excite you. Not understanding the root cause of our feelings and directing our energy into solving a vague problem will only cause further dissatisfaction.

Psychology.description: dealing with cravings you don’t want to give in to
Psychology.title: Urge Surfing
Psychology.content:
**Urge Surfing** is a technique for dealing with cravings or impulses you don’t want to give in to. I came across this concept because I often find myself reaching for my smartphone whenever I’m faced with difficult tasks, stress, or anxiety.

The idea behind urge surfing is that urges rise and fall like waves — and that you can learn to ride them without being overwhelmed.

**How it works:**

1. **Observe** the urge without judging or suppressing it. What do you feel in your body? What thoughts arise?
2. **Acknowledge** the urge. It’s a normal part of human experience.
3. **Surf** the urge like a wave: notice it building, peaking, and eventually fading.
4. **Time** the urge. Most urges don’t last longer than 30 minutes if you don’t act on them.
5. **Redirect** your focus. Engage in something else — like walking or listening to music — while the urge passes.

**Important:**  
Urge surfing is not about avoiding or suppressing urges. It’s about noticing and accepting them, which helps reduce their power over time.

Psychology.description: the secret sauce for creativity and joy
Psychology.title: Pockets of Stillness
Psychology.content:
I tend to see work and hustle as valuable and time "properly" spent. Learning, improving and growing is good. However, I sometimes forget that breaks and activities without a specific purpose are at least as important - if not more so.

Perhaps that’s why the idea of Pockets of Stillness resonated with me when I came across it: 


> **Build pockets of stillness into your life.** 
>
> Meditate. Go for walks. Ride your bike going nowhere in particular. There is a creative purpose to daydreaming, even to boredom. The best ideas come to us when we stop actively trying to coax the muse into manifesting and let the fragments of experience float around our unconscious mind in order to click into new combinations. Without this essential stage of unconscious processing, the entire flow of the creative process is broken. Most important, sleep. Besides being the greatest creative aphrodisiac, sleep also affects our every waking moment, dictates our social rhythm, and even mediates our negative moods. Be as religious and disciplined about your sleep as you are about your work. We tend to wear our ability to get by on little sleep as some sort of badge of honor that validates our work ethic. But what it really is is a profound failure of self-respect and of priorities. What could possibly be more important than your health and your sanity, from which all else springs?  [^1] 

[^1]: https://www.themarginalian.org/2024/10/22/marginalian-18/?utm_source=DenseDiscovery-318

Psychology.description: choosing a larger reward later over a smaller one now
Psychology.title: Delayed gratification
Psychology.content:
"Are you curious?". This is the slogan from a TV commercial that I remember from my childhood. Children are shown being given a "surprise egg", a chocolate egg with a toy inside. They are also given the condition that they will get a second one if they don't eat it until the adult returns. Spoiler: the children have eaten the chocolate.

It's funny that I'm now encountering this psychological effect again 13 years later in the form of the concept of "delayed gratification".

Delayed gratification is the ability to resist the temptation for an immediate reward and wait for a later reward that is usually greater. It’s about being patient and making choices that might be harder now but will lead to better outcomes in the future.

first read about the concept on Marcels Blog[^1]

[^1]: https://marcel.io/posts/life-affirming-choices

Psychology.description: a small change that leads to transformative effects in multiple areas of life
Psychology.title: Keystone Habit
Psychology.content:
**What's a keystone?**
A keystone is the central stone at the top of an arch. It holds all the other stones in place and makes the arch strong.

**What's a keystone habit?**
A keystone habit is a key habit that can lead to big changes in other areas of your life. When you focus on this one habit, it can help you improve many things, like your health or mood. Examples include exercising regularly or getting enough sleep. [^1] 

A keystone habit...

1. influences how we see ourselves
2. creates a chain reaction
3. helps us great willpower

[^1]: The Power of Habit – Charles Duhigg

Technology.title: JOMO
Technology.content:
**Joy of missing out**  – feeling content with staying in and disconnecting as form of self-care.

--- 

Closely linked to digital media consumption and digital minimalism:

**JOMO = best friend**
Think of JOMO as your new best friend that loves to help you enjoy life offline. Practicing digital minimalism is basically saying “no thanks” to the endless scroll and “yes please” to stuff you really enjoy in the real life.

**evil algorithms = antagonist**
Apps with sophisticated algorithms that are designed to keep you in the application as long as possible and get your attention are the antagonist of JOMO.

Technology.description: Why we make impulsive decisions in digital environments
Technology.title: Decision-Making without Social Regulation
Technology.content:
Today, I came across the following thesis in Joan Westenberg’s newsletter[^1]: 
McDonald’s discovered that customers who order through self-service kiosks make different choices than those ordering from a human cashier. Without social signals like eye contact or pauses in conversation, people tend to order more – for example, two burgers instead of one. The absence of social control from others leads to impulses being expressed more freely. This shows that digital interfaces are not only more convenient, but also strip away natural psychological barriers that would otherwise regulate our behavior. (Good news for McDonalds)

## Social influences shape our decisions

In the real world, our decisions are often influenced by social signals. When interacting with others, we subconsciously pay attention to their reactions – a quick glance, a raised eyebrow, or a pause in conversation can make us reflect. These small cues help us regulate our behavior and reconsider impulsive decisions.

## Decisions in digital environments without social control

In the digital space, direct social signals that make us reflect are absent. Without eye contact or reactions from others, we act more impulsively.

- **Online shopping:** A single click, and the shopping cart fills with impulse purchases. No one is watching critically, so we think less.
- **Online dating:** Without a real person in front of us, we swipe quickly, rather than taking time for a deeper connection. The person, with their complex social depth, disappears behind images that are superficially judged.
- **Social media:** Without direct consequences, we post unfiltered opinions that we might hold back in a real conversation.

Digital platforms make decisions easier – but often also more thoughtless (and this on purpose).

[^1]: https://www.joanwestenberg.com/when-screens-remove-our-better-angels/
